div.head: An Ordinance of Parliament for the taking away of the Book of Common-Prayer, and for the e≈øtabli≈øhing and putting in execution of the Directory for the publique Wor≈øhip of God.
div.p:
THe Lords and Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, taking into ≈øerious con≈øideration the manifold Inconveniences that have ari≈øen by the Book of Common-Prayer in this Kingdom, and re≈øolving, according to their Covenant, to reform Religion according to the Word of God, and the Example of the be≈øt Reformed Churches, have Con≈øulted with the Reverend, Pious and Learned Divines, called together to that purpo≈øe; And do judge it nece≈ø≈øary that the ≈øaid Book of Common-Prayer be aboli≈øhed, & the Directory for the Publique Wor≈øhip of God, herein after mentioned, be e≈øtabli≈øhed and ob≈øerved in all the Churches within this Kingdom: Be it therefore Ordained by the Lords and Commons A≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, That the Statute of the ≈øecond and third years of King Edward the ≈øixth, Intituled, The Penalty for not u≈øing Vniformity of Service, and Admini≈øtration of Sacraments, &c. And the Statute
of the fifth and ≈øixt yeares of the ≈øame King, Intituled, Vniformity of Prayer, and Admini≈øtration of Sacraments, ≈øhall be u≈øed in the Church: And ≈øo much of the Statute of the fir≈øt year of Queen Elizabeth, Intituled, There ≈øhall be Vniformity of Prayer and Admini≈øtration of Sacraments, as concernes the ≈øaid Book of Common-Prayer, and the Vniformity of Prayer, and Admini≈øtration of the Sacraments: And ≈øo much of the Statute of the fifth year of the ≈øame Queen, Intituled, By who≈øe Order, the Bible, and Book of Common-Prayer ≈øhall be Tran≈ølated into the Welch Tongue, as concerns the Book of Common-Prayer: And ≈øo much of the Statute of the eighth year of the ≈øame Queen, Intituled, All Acts made by any per≈øon ≈øince Primo Eliz. for the Con≈øecrating, Inve≈øting, &c. of any Archbi≈øhop, or Bi≈øhop, ≈øhall be good, as concerns the ≈øaid Book; Be, and ≈øtand from henceforth Repealed, void, and of none effect, to all intents, con≈øtructions, and purpo≈øes what≈øoever; And that the ≈øaid book of Common-Prayer, ≈øhall not remain, or be from henceforth u≈øed in any Church, Chappell, or place of Publique Wor≈øhip, within the Kingdom of England, or Dominion of Wales; And that the Directory for Publique Wor≈øhip herein ≈øet
forth, ≈øhall be henceforth u≈øed, pur≈øued, and ob≈øerved, according to the true intent and meaning of this Ordinance, in all Exerci≈øes of the Publique Wor≈øhip of God, in every Congregation, Church, Chappell, and place of Publique Wor≈øhip within this Kingdom of England, and Dominion of Wales; Which Directory for the Publique Wor≈øhip of God, with the Preface thereof followeth. And it is further Ordained by the Authority afore≈øaid, That there ≈øhall be provided at the charge of every Pari≈øh, or Chappelry in this Realm of England, and Dominion of Wales, a fair Regi≈øter Book of Velim, to be kept by the Mini≈øter and other Officers of the Church; And that the Names of all Children Baptized, and of their Parents, and of the time of their Birth and Baptizing, ≈øhall be written and ≈øet down by the Mini≈øter therein; And al≈øo the Names of all per≈øons Married there, and the time of their Marriage; And al≈øo the Names of all per≈øons Buried in that Pari≈øh, and the time of their Death and Buriall: And that the ≈øaid Book ≈øhall be ≈øhewed by ≈øuch as keep the ≈øame, to all per≈øons rea≈øonably de≈øiring to ≈øearch for the Birth, Baptizing, Marriage, or Buriall of any per≈øon therein Regi≈øtred, and to take a Copy, or procure a Certificate thereof.

div.head: A DIRECTORY FOR The Publique Wor≈øhip OF GOD In the three KINGDOMES.
THE PREFACE.
div.p:
IN the beginning of the ble≈ø≈øed Reformation, our wi≈øe and pious Ance≈øtors took care to ≈øet forth an Order for Redre≈ø≈øe of many things, which they, then, by the VVord di≈øcovered to be Vain, Erroneous, Super≈øtitious, and Idolatrous, in the Publique VVor≈øhip of God. This occa≈øioned many Godly and Learned men to rejoyce much in the Book of Common-Prayer at that time ≈øet forth; Becau≈øe the Ma≈ø≈øe, and
the re≈øt of the Latine-Service being removed, the Publique VVor≈øhip was celebrated in our own Tongue; many of the common People al≈øo received benefit by hearing the Scriptures read in their own Language, which formerly were unto them as a Book that is ≈øealed.

Howbeit, long and ≈øad Experience hath made it manife≈øt, That the Leiturgie u≈øed in the Church of England, (notwith≈øtanding all the pains and Religious intentions of the Compilers of it) hath proved an offence, not only to many of the Godly at home; but al≈øo to the Reformed Churches abroad. For, not to ≈øpeak of urging the Reading of all the Prayers, which very greatly increa≈øed the burden of it; the many unprofitable and burden≈øome Ceremonies, contained in it, have occa≈øioned much mi≈øchief, as well by di≈øquieting the Con≈øciences of many godly Mini≈øters and people who could not
yield unto them, as by depriving them of the Ordinances of God, which they might not enjoy without conforming or Sub≈øcribing to tho≈øe Ceremonies. Sundry good Chri≈øtians have been by means thereof, kept from the Lords Table, and divers able and faithfull Mini≈øters debarred from the exerci≈øe of their Mini≈øtery (to the endangering of many Thou≈øand Souls, in a time of ≈øuch ≈øcarcity of faithfull Pa≈øtors) and ≈øpoiled of their livelyhood, to the undoing of them and their Families. Prelates and their Faction have laboured to rai≈øe the E≈øtimation of it to ≈øuch an height, as if there were no other VVor≈øhip, or way of VVor≈øhip of God among≈øt us, but onely the Service-Book; to the great hinderance of the Preaching of the VVord, and (in ≈øome places, e≈øpecially of late) to the ju≈øtling of it out, as unnece≈ø≈øary; or (at be≈øt) as far inferior to the Reading of Common-Prayer, which
was made no better then an Idol by many Ignorant and Super≈øtitious People, vvho plea≈øing them≈øelves in their pre≈øence at that Service, and their Lip-labour in bearing a part in it, have thereby hardened them≈øelves in their ignorance and carele≈øne≈ø≈øe of ≈øaving knowledge and true piety.

In the mean time Papi≈øts boa≈øted, that the Book was a compliance with them in a great part of their Service, and ≈øo were not a little confirmed in their Super≈øtition and Idolatry, expecting rather our return to them, than endeavouring the Reformation of them≈øelves: In which expectation they were of late very much incouraged, when, upon the pretended warrantablene≈ø≈øe of impo≈øing of the former Ceremonies, new ones were dayly obtruded upon the Church.

Adde hereunto (which was not fore≈øeen, but ≈øince hath come to pa≈ø≈øe) that the Leiturgie hath been a great means, as on the
one hand to make and increa≈øe an idle and unedifying Mini≈øtery, which contented it ≈øelf with ≈øet Forms made to their hands by others, without putting forth them≈øelves to exerci≈øe the gift of Prayer, with which our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt plea≈øeth to furni≈øh all his Servants whom he calls to that office: So on the other ≈øide it hath been (and ever would be, if continued) a matter of endle≈ø≈øe ≈øtrife and contention in the Church, and a ≈ønare both to many godly and faithfull Mini≈øters, who have been per≈øecuted and ≈øilenced upon that occa≈øion, and to others of hopefull parts, many of which have been, and more ≈øtill would be, diverted from all thoughts of the Mini≈øtery to other ≈øtudies; e≈øpecially in the≈øe latter times, wherein God vouch≈øafeth to his people more and better means for the di≈øcovery of Error and Super≈øtition, and for attaining of knowledge in the my≈øteries of godline≈øs, and gifts in Preaching and Prayer.

Upon the≈øe, and many the like weighty con≈øiderations, in reference to the whole Book in generall, and becau≈øe of divers particulars contained in it; not from any love to Novelty, or intention to di≈øparage our fir≈øt Reformers (of whom we are per≈øwaded that were they now alive, they would joyn with us in this work, and whom we acknowledge as Excellent In≈øtruments rai≈øed by God to begin the purging and building of his Hou≈øe, and de≈øire they may be had of us and Po≈øterity in everla≈øting Remembrance, with thankfulne≈ø≈øe and honour;) but that we may in ≈øome mea≈øure an≈øwer the gracious Providence of God, which at this time calleth upon us for further Reformation, and may ≈øatisfy our own Con≈øciences, and an≈øwer the expectation of other Reformed Churches, and the de≈øires of many of the godly among our ≈øelves, and withall give ≈øome publique Te≈øtimony of our endeavors
for Uniformity in Divine Wor≈øhip, which we have promi≈øed in our Solemn League and Covenant: VVe have, after earne≈øt and frequent calling upon the Name of God, and after much Con≈øultation, not with fle≈øh and blood, but with his holy VVord, re≈øolved to lay a≈øide the former Leiturgie, with the many Rites and Ceremonies formerly u≈øed in the VVor≈øhip of God: And have agreed upon this following Directory for all the parts of Publique VVor≈øhip, at ordinary and extraordinary times.

VVherein our care hath been to hold forth ≈øuch things as are of Divine In≈øtitution in every Ordinance; and other things we have endeavoured to ≈øet forth according to the Rules of Chri≈øtian Prudence, agreeable to the generall Rules of the VVord of God. Our meaning therein being onely that the generall heads, the ≈øen≈øe and ≈øcope of the Prayers and other parts of Publique VVor≈øhip
being known to all, there may be a con≈øent of all the Churches, in tho≈øe things that contain the ≈øub≈øtance of the Service and VVor≈øhip of God; And the Mini≈øters may be hereby directed in their Admini≈øtrations to keep like ≈øoundne≈ø≈øe in Doctrine and Prayer; and may, if need be, have ≈øome help and furniture: And yet ≈øo, as they become not hereby ≈ølothfull and negligent in ≈øtirring up the gifts of Chri≈øt in them: But, that each one, by meditation, by taking heed to him≈øelf and the Flock of God committed to him, and by wi≈øe ob≈øerving the wayes of Divine Providence, may be carefull to furni≈øh his heart and tongue with further, or other materials of Prayer and Exhortation, as ≈øhall be needfull upon all occa≈øions.

body.head: A DIRECTORY FOR Publique Prayer, Reading the Holy Scriptures, Singing of P≈øalmes, Preaching of the Word, Admini≈øtration of the Sacraments, and other parts of the Publique Wor≈øhip of God, Ordinary, & Extraordinary.

div.head: Of the A≈ø≈øembling of the Congregation, and their Behaviour in the Publique Wor≈øhip of God.
div.p:
WHen the Congregation is to meete for Publique Wor≈øhip, the people (having before prepared their hearts thereunto) ought all to come, and joyne therein: not ab≈øenting them≈øelves from the Publique
Ordinances, through negligence, or upon pretence of Private meetings.
Let all enter the A≈ø≈øembly, not irreverently, but in a grave and ≈øeemly manner, taking their ≈øeates or places without Adoration, or Bowing them≈øelves towards one place or other.
The Congregation being a≈ø≈øembled; the Mini≈øter, after ≈øolemne calling on them to the wor≈øhiping of the great name of God, is to begin with Prayer;

p.hi:
In all Reverence and Humility acknowledging the incomprehen≈øible Greatne≈ø≈øe and Maje≈øty of the Lord, (in who≈øe pre≈øence they doe then in a ≈øpeciall manner appeare) and their own vilene≈ø≈øe and unworthine≈ø≈øe to approach ≈øo neare him; with their utter inability of them≈øelves, to ≈øo great a Work: And humbly be≈øeeching him for Pardon, A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and Acceptance in the whole Service then to bee performed; and for a Ble≈ø≈øing
on that particular portion of his Word then to bee read: and all, in the Name and Mediation of the Lord Je≈øus Christ.

div.p: The Publique Wor≈øhip being begun, the people are wholly to attend upon it; forbearing to Reade any thing, except what the Mini≈øter is then reading or citing; and ab≈øtaining much more from all private whi≈øperings, conferences, ≈øalutations, or doing reverence to any per≈øons pre≈øent, or comming in; as al≈øo from all gazing, ≈øleeping, and other undecent behaviour, which may di≈øturbe the Mini≈øter or people, or hinder them≈øelves or others in the ≈øervice of God.

If any through nece≈ø≈øity be hindred from being pre≈øent at the beginning, they ought not, when they come into the Congregation, to betake them≈øelves to their private Devotions, but reverently to compo≈øe them≈øelves to joyne with the A≈ø≈øembly, in that Ordinance of God which is then in hand.

div.head: Of Publique Reading of the holy Scriptures.
div.p: REading of the Word in the Congregation, being part of the publique Wor≈øhip of God, (wherin we acknowledge our dependence upon him, and ≈øubjection to him) and one Means ≈øanctified by him for the edifying of his People, is to bee performed by the Pa≈øtors and Teachers.
Howbeit, ≈øuch as intend the Mini≈øtery, may occa≈øionally both reade the Word, and exerci≈øe their gift in Preaching in the Congregation, if allowed by the Presbytery thereunto.

All the Canonicall Books of the Old and New Te≈øtament, (but none of tho≈øe which are commonly called Apocrypha) ≈øhall be publiquely read in the vulgar Tongue, out of the be≈øt allowed Tran≈ølation, di≈øtinctly, that all may heare and under≈øtand.

How large a portion ≈øhall be read at once, is left to the wi≈ødome of the Mini≈øter: But it is convenient that ordinarily one Chapter of each Te≈øtament bee read at every meeting; and ≈øometimes more, where the
Chapters be ≈øhort, or the coherence of matter requireth it.

It is requi≈øite that all the Canonical books bee read over in order, that the people may be better acquainted with the whole Body of the Scriptures: And ordinarily, where the Reading in either Te≈øtament endeth on one Lords day, it is to begin the next.
Wee commend al≈øo the more frequent reading of ≈øuch Scriptures, as hee that readeth ≈øhall thinke be≈øt for edification of his Hearers; as the Book of P≈øalmes, and ≈øuch like.

When the Mini≈øter, who readeth, ≈øhall judge it nece≈ø≈øary to expound any part of what is read, let it not bee done untill the whole Chapter, or P≈øalme bee ended: and regard is alwayes to be had unto the time, that neither Preaching or other Ordinance bee ≈øtraitned, or rendred tedious. Which Rule is to be ob≈øerved in all other publique performances.

Be≈øide Publique Reading of the Holy Scriptures, every per≈øon that can reade, is to be exhorted to reade the Scriptures privately
(and all others that cannot reade, if not di≈øabled by age, or otherwi≈øe, are likewi≈øe to bee exhorted to learne to reade) and to have a Bible.

div.head: Of Publike Prayer before the Sermon.
div.p: AFter Reading of the Word (and ≈øinging of the P≈øalme) the Mini≈øter who is to Preach, is to endeavour to get his own, and his Hearers hearts to be rightly affected with their Sinnes, that they may all mourn in ≈øen≈øe thereof before the Lord, and hunger and thir≈øt after the grace of God in Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, by proceeding to a more full Confe≈ø≈øion of Sinne with ≈øhame and holy confu≈øion of face; and to Call upon the Lord to this effect;

p.hi:
To acknowledge our great ≈øinfulne≈ø≈øe; Fir≈øt, by rea≈øon of Originall ≈øin, which (be≈øide the guilt that makes us liable to everla≈øting Damnation) is the ≈øeed of all
other ≈øinnes, hath depraved and poy≈øoned all the faculties and powers of Soule and Body, doth defile our best actions, and (were it not re≈øtrained, or our hearts renewed by Grace) would breake forth into innumerable tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions, and greate≈øt rebellions against the Lord, that ever were committed by the vilest of the ≈øons of Men. And, next, by rea≈øon of Actuall ≈øins, our own ≈øins, the ≈øins of Magi≈øtrates, of Mini≈øters, and of the whole Nation, unto which wee are many wayes acce≈ø≈øory. Which ≈øins of ours receive many fearefull aggravations, wee having broken all the Commandements of the holy, just, and good Law of God, doing that which is forbidden, and leaving undone what is enjoyned; and that not onely out of Ignorance, and Infirmity, but al≈øo more pre≈øumptuou≈øly again≈øt the light of our
Minds, checks of our Con≈øciences, and motions of his own Holy Spirit to the contrary, ≈øo that we have no cloak for our ≈øins; Yea, not onely de≈øpi≈øing the riches of Gods goodne≈ø≈øe, forbearance and long-≈øuffering, but ≈øtanding out again≈øt many invitations and offers of grace in the Go≈øpel, not endeavouring as wee ought to receive Chri≈øt into our hearts by Faith, or to walke worthy of him in our lives.

To bewaile our blindne≈ø≈øe of minde, hardne≈ø≈øe of heart, unbelief, impenitency, ≈øecurity, lukewarmne≈ø≈øe, barrenne≈ø≈øe, our not endeavouring after mortification and newne≈ø≈øe of life; nor after the exerci≈øe of godline≈ø≈øe in the power thereof; and that the best of us have not ≈øo ≈øtedfa≈øtly walked with God, kept our garments ≈øo un≈øpotted, nor been ≈øo zealous of his glory, and the good of others,
as wee ought: And to mourn over ≈øuch other ≈øins as the Congregation is particularly guilty of; notwith≈øtanding the manifold and great Mercies of our God, the Love of Christ, the Light of the Go≈øpel, and Reformation of Religion, our own purpo≈øes, promi≈øes, vows, ≈øolemn Covenant, and other ≈øpeciall obligations to the contrary.

To acknowledge and confe≈ø≈øe, that, as wee are convinced of our guilt, ≈øo, out of a deep ≈øen≈øe thereof, wee judge our ≈øelves unworthy of the ≈ømallest benefits, most worthy of Gods fiercest wrath, and of all the Cur≈øes of the Law and heavie≈øt Judgements inflicted upon the mo≈øt rebellious Sinners; and that hee might mo≈øt ju≈øtly take his Kingdome and Go≈øpel from us, plague us with all ≈øorts of ≈øpirituall and temporall judgements in this life, and after ca≈øt us into
utter Darkne≈ø≈øe, in the Lake that burneth with fire and brim≈øtone, where is weeping, and gna≈øhing of teeth for evermore.

Notwith≈øtanding all which, To draw neare to the Throne of Grace, encouraging our ≈øelves with hope of a gracious An≈øwer of our Prayers, in the riches and all-≈øufficiency of that onely one oblation, the ≈øatisfaction and interce≈ø≈øion of the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt at the right hand of his Father, and our Father; and, in confidence of the exceeding great and precious promi≈øes of mercy and grace in the new Covenant, through the ≈øame Mediator thereof, to deprecate the heavy wrath and cur≈øe of God, which wee are not able to avoid, or beare; and humbly, and earne≈øtly to ≈øupplicate for mercy in the free and full remi≈ø≈øion of all our ≈øins, and that onely for the bitter
≈øufferings and pretious merits of that our onely Saviour Je≈øus Chri≈øt.
